answers: Arthur Holly Compton [accept Compton generator or Compton tube; accept reduced Compton wavelength]
parts: Name this quantity often symbolized by theta. Higher centrifugal forces experienced at small values of this quantity cause a characteristic “bulge” of planets.
This fictitious force depends on both the magnitude and sign of the latitude. This force causes rightward deflection of objects in both the Northern and Southern hemispheres.

As an undergraduate, this scientist invented a device to measure latitude or the Earth’s rotation speed by rotating a ring 180 degrees and measuring the velocity of oil particles inside it. Field theoretic effects become significant below a length scale named for this scientist.

answers: bottle cap [or crown cap, or crown cork, or crown seal; prompt on cork]
obsolescence [or word forms like obsolete; or planned obsolescence, or built-in obsolescence, or premature obsolescence]
parts: This invention of William Painter was initially applied to another product with a foot-powered apparatus. This innovative disposable product allowed stores to stock certain items upright instead of on their sides.

Alfred P. Sloan introduced the “planned” form of this product design concept while he was CEO of General Motors. This concept deliberately makes long-lasting products less functional over time, rendering them disposable.

This material was initially created as a disposable alternative to ivory billiard balls, but was phased out due to its tendency to explode. This material is better known as the base of the film in the initial Kodak camera.

answers: Anactoria [accept “Ode to Anactoria”; prompt on, but DO NOT REVEAL, Sappho 31 by asking “What is the alternate title of the poem?”]
parts: Name this person who titles a poem that describes “the heart in my chest on wings” and “tongue breaks and thin / fire racing under skin.”
The line “He seems to me equal to gods” opens this poet’s “Ode to Anactoria,” which is her 31st fragment. This ancient Greek “tenth Muse” also wrote “Hymn to Aphrodite.”

Sappho’s line “He seems to me equal to gods” was adapted into a poem about this woman, which is written in sapphic meter. The speaker of a poem asks this woman to give them “a thousand kisses, then another hundred.”
Name this author whose Inferno inspired an eponymous piano sonata and choral symphony by Liszt.

Among the other literary inspirations for Liszt’s work was this character, who names a set of three virtuosic pieces beginning with “The Dance in the Village Inn” that are sometimes paired with his “Bagatelle (“bag-uh-TELL”) without Tonality.”

Liszt wrote two piano pieces with this name based on the lives of St. Francis of Assisi and St. Francis of Paola. A violin showpiece by Henryk Wieniawski (“v’yen-YAHF-skee”) also has this French-language title.

answers: realism [accept subaltern realism, neorealism, or structural realism]
Westphalian system [or Westphalian sovereignty; accept Westfailure]
parts: Give this outdated two-word term for developing countries, which was first used during the Cold War to denote poor nations aligned with neither the U.S.S.R. nor the United States.

Ayoob developed a “subaltern” variety of this theory of international relations. Liberalism rejects the emphasis placed on power politics by this school of thought, whose “neo-” form was developed by Kenneth Waltz.

Ayoob called for “weak” postcolonial states to pursue the “ideal” of this system, in which states have “effectiveness and legitimacy.” The title of Susan Strange’s magnum opus puns on this term for the international system of state sovereignty.

answers: Thousand Talents Program [or Thousand Talents Plan or Qiān rén jìhuà]
parts: Name this alliteratively-named program. The CPC introduced this program in 2010 to recruit successful Chinese researchers living abroad, as well as famous non-Chinese scientists, to positions at Chinese universities.

Charles Lieber, a chemistry professor at this university, was arrested during a crackdown on alleged espionage associated with Thousand Talents. Stephen Jay Gould and E. O. Wilson had a long feud during their careers at this university.
Lieber was accused of participating in the Thousand Talents program via a university based in this Chinese city. This city was the first identified location of COVID-19.

answers: Oswald Mosley [or Sir Oswald Ernald Mosley, 6th Baronet]
parts: Name these objects that were also worn by a group of World War I soldiers who would swim across rivers clenching daggers between their teeth, inspiring their use by the later MVSN.

Ironically, a 2018 “blackshirt” rally based on Periyar’s teachings opposed this ideology in Tamil Nadu, even though the original Italian blackshirts were deeply committed to this ideology under their leader Benito Mussolini.
The Blackshirt also served as the newspaper for the British Union of Fascists, which was led by this politician who organized an antisemitic march that ended in the violent Battle of Cable Street.
Name this biological response to things like final exams and writing quizbowl questions on a deadline.

In rats, stress-related activation of glucocorticoid receptors can halt this process, which begins with either a single tetanus or multiple weaker stimuli. Subunits of the dodecameric CaMKII (“cam-K-two”) are activated during the early stages of this process, which can then phosphorylate other subunits or be exchanged with other CamKII complexes.

Long-term potentiation is prototypically studied in the CA1 region of this brain structure, which is responsible for the formation of long-term memories. Damage to this structure’s dentate gyrus can cause amnesia.

answers: Erikson [accept Kai Erikson or Erik Erikson]
smokejumpers [accept wildland firefighters, firemen, or firejumpers]
parts: Give this last name of Kai, a sociologist of disaster. His father of this surname theorized eight stages defined by conflicts like “trust vs. mistrust” and “identity vs. confusion.”

Michael Eric Dyson studied the “color of disaster” in a book about this event, whose “women” title a book by Elaine Enarson. Discussions of environmental racism often cite the response to this 2005 hurricane.

The organizational theorist Karl Weick’s analysis of “the collapse of sensemaking in organizations” was inspired by Norman Maclean’s account of the 1949 Mann Gulch disaster, in which 13 people with this job died.

answers: William S. Burroughs [or William Seward Burroughs II or William Lee] (The novel is Naked Lunch.)
parts: Name this genre. Charlie and J.P.’s children navigate between life in Texas and Colorado in Mary Karr’s The Liars’ Club, which is credited with a resurgence in this genre.
In Patti Smith’s memoir Just Kids, she recalls an “unspoken routine” in which she would wait in the Hotel Chelsea lobby to hail cabs for this author, who set a novel in Tangier and Interzone.

Karr claims the “Symbolist idea” that “being tortured is a virtue” originates from this poet. In Just Kids, Smith describes her “unrequited love for” this French poet of Illuminations and “The Drunken Boat.”

answers: urine [or equivalents such as pee or piss; accept Čůrající postavy]
soup [accept Campbell’s Soup or Campbell’s Soup Cans; accept specific kinds like tomato soup]
parts: Name this liquid heavily employed in Nitsch’s performance art. In 2019, artist Jordan Eagles “drenched” the walls of the Andy Warhol Museum with this fluid, which Eagles also used in a 2015 “Mirror” sculpture.

Warhol himself utilized unusual fluids in his art, as evidenced by his use of this bodily fluid in his “Oxidation Paintings.” This liquid also titles a Prague sculpture of two men facing each other by David Černý.
Cans of this semi-liquid food are a recurring motif in Warhol’s work. Autographed cans of this liquid sold at a price sixty times the original at the 1964 exhibit “The American Supermarket.”

answers: Mohamed Siad Barre [or Maxamed Siyaad Barre]
parts: Name this customary Somali legal system. This legal system’s main principle is compensatory justice adjudicated by tribal elders through informal arbitrations.
Xeer predates this Islamic legal system, which was introduced after refugees from the first hijrah settled in the country. This legal system is still practiced alongside xeer.

This Somali dictator attempted to abolish the disparate Somali legal systems and place the country under a single system of civil law. This man instigated the Ogaden War in an attempt to establish a “Greater Somalia.”

answers: the crow of a rooster [accept onomatopoeic renderings like cock-a-doodle-doo or gaggalagú; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name these creatures, one of which terrorized the peasants of 16th-century Warsaw until it was removed with a rake. These wingless creatures could be displaced using springs of the rue plant.

Though medieval accounts often ended with the basilisk gazing in a mirror and exploding, they could also be killed by being exposed to this stimulus. At the beginning of Ragnarok, this sound will echo from Hel to Valhalla.

The remains of a basilisk could be ground into a powder and combined with red copper, blood, and vinegar to produce this precious metal. Transmuting base materials into this metal was the goal of many alchemists.

answers: temperature AND entropy [prompt on T and S; prompt on T–S diagram; prompt on partial answers]
non-equilibrium thermodynamics [or synonyms like out of equilibrium thermodynamics]
parts: Name this pair of conjugate thermodynamic variables. The product of these two variables is subtracted from the internal energy to get Helmholtz free energy, and from enthalpy to get Gibbs free energy.

For a reversible reaction, temperature times the differential of entropy equals the differential of this quantity. The change in internal energy of a system equals this quantity, symbolized Q, minus the work done by the system.

Heat conduction has been shown to not obey the principle of maximum entropy production, a foundational rule in this branch of thermodynamics. This branch of thermodynamics has produced relations such as the Crooks fluctuation theorem by considering the second law of thermodynamics to only be true when averaged over time.
Name this play centering on the twins Viola and Sebastian. In that adaptation of this play, the jester Feste and the steward Malvolio are both played by women.

The Simon Godwin-directed National Theater adaptation of this other play features a revolving stage and an emerging submarine. In this play, Enobarbus claims, “Age cannot wither her, nor custom stale her infinite variety.”

Simon Godwin’s production of this play adds electric rock to a song which declares that a woman “excels each mortal thing / Upon the dull earth dwelling.” In this play, the maid Lucetta delivers a love letter to her mistress.
Name this author and activist who performed in productions such as the ballet Southland, which portrayed a lynching. This dancer also choreographed Barrelhouse and Woman with a Cigar.
Like her contemporary and fellow dancer Pearl Primus, Dunham engaged in this type of work in the Caribbean. Dunham initially visited Haiti and Jamaica in order to engage in this kind of work.

Dunham directed the posthumous 1972 premiere of this man’s opera Treemonisha. This man’s other opera A Guest of Honor is lost, and he is best known for piano compositions such as the “Maple Leaf Rag.”

answers: licking a rock [or tasting a rock; accept wetting a finger and touching a rock]
parts: Name this analytical technique that can be used to distinguish chrysocolla from other blue-green minerals in the field. You can technically use this technique to identify coal, but it’s much easier to just look at it.
The easiest mineral to identify by licking is this cubic mineral formed from evaporated sodium chloride.

Flavor is typically less important than whether the tongue sticks to the surface, as it does when licking this white mineral. The group of this 1-to-1 phyllosilicate mineral is contrasted with that of the 2-to-1 montmorillonite (“mont-mor-ee-yon-ite”).

answers: Crimean War [or Krymskaya Voyna or Guerre de Crimée]

Battle of Mukden [accept Mukdenskoye Srazheniye, Hōten Kaisen, or Fèngtiān Huìzhàn; do not accept or prompt on “Mukden Incident,” which was a different event that occurred in the leadup to World War II]
Alaska [accept Russian America or Russkaya Amerika; or Alyaska, Alaasikaq, or Alaas’kaq]
parts: During this war, the Russian ship Aurora was chased by enemy forces from Peru to Siberia. Russian forces successfully evacuated the besieged port of Petropavlovsk during this war by exploiting confusion regarding Sakhalin’s status as an island rather than a peninsula.

Japan deployed its entire land army to win this largest land battle of the Russo-Japanese War. After Russia lost this battle near modern-day Shenyang, Alexei Kuropatkin resigned from his position as commander.
In this territory, Russian colonists fought against the Tlingit at the Battle of Sitka. This territory was later sold to the United States in 1867.

answers: Yasunari Kawabata [accept names in either order]
tea bowl [accept anything mentioning a bowl used during tea ceremony; prompt on bowl by asking “what is it used for?”; do not accept or prompt on “teacup”]
parts: Name this novel about the relationship between Kikuji and Fumiko, which develops after the death of Fumiko’s mother, Mrs. Ota.
Thousand Cranes is a novel by this Japanese author, who wrote about Honinbo Shūsai’s retirement game in The Master of Go.

In Thousand Cranes, Fumiko angrily tells Kikuji to destroy one of these items that she had gifted him. When he refuses, Fumiko shatters another of these items, which has a trace of her mother’s lipstick.

answers: Philosophy and the Mirror of Nature
parts: Name this 1979 book that advocates the dissolution of many traditional problems of metaphysics and epistemology, which it claims result from faulty metaphors like the “Eye of the Mind.”
Philosophy and the Mirror of Nature is by this American philosopher. This thinker developed his concept of “ironism” in his book Contingency, Irony, and Solidarity.

Rorty is often identified with a postmodern form of this school of thought called its “neo-” version. William James’s book on this philosophy refers to it as “a new name for some old ways of thinking.”
